The Italian, ranked 95th in the world, defeated Djokovic as lucky loser at last year's Indian Wells. He will hope that even more people know his name after his clash with Jannik Sinner on Centre Court. Yulia Putintseva called a spectator “dangerous” and “crazy” before suggesting that they could be carrying a knife. Putintseva was beaten 6-0 6-0 by Amanda Anisimova yesterday and, midway through the first set, she alerted an individual to the umpire. She asked the umpire: “Can you take him out? I'm not going to continue playing until he leaves. These people are dangerous, they're crazy. Maybe he has a knife and he will attack after, I don't know.” Wimbledon say a situation on court was dealt with. We're pushing 32 degrees Celsius on Court 1 and it's sweltering even in the shade. Lord knows how Jannik Sinner and Luca Nardi are feeling in the direct sunlight. Scared, probably. The heat got the better of a few players yesterday. Top seed Sinner will hope he doesn't suffer the same fate today. It's an all-Italian clash to get him going, and I'm sure he'll want to be back under the AC as soon as possible. Manchester United fan Jack Draper has received a good luck message from the club ahead of his Wimbledon first-round match this afternoon. The No. 4 seed will start his quest for glory in his home Grand Slam when he faces Sebastian Baez. United wished him well on X, posting: "British no.1 Jack Draper kicks off his #Wimbledon campaign later today! Wishing you the best of luck, Jack." British no.1 Jack Draper kicks off his #Wimbledon campaign later today! \ud83d\udc40Wishing you the best of luck, Jack \ud83e\udd1e pic.twitter.com/0sqax0skpS Elisabetta Cocciaretto has revealed that she was in hospital during Wimbledon last year. The Italian is the latest underdog to take down a seeded star in the first round this time around, sensationally beating Jessica Pegula in straight sets. Cocciaretto said on court: “For sure I played with a player like her before, Iga [Swiatek], Aryna [Sabalenka], all of those players that you have to do the best you can on the court and take the little chances they give you. “I tried to do the opposite to what I did in the other matches. To be more aggressive, to go for it and don't think about winning or losing the point, just do your best. I think I did a great job today and I'm super happy about that. “I had a lot of stops last year. I was in hospital and I was sick for one month and I couldn't play here. That's why I was so pumped to play because I think it's the best tournament and grass is always special to play. “I don't think too much about my ranking right now. With the ranking, you can play other tournaments. The journey of tennis is so long and up and down always. You have to adapt yourself and enjoy and accept what happens in life.” No. 3 seed Jessica Pegula has suffered the biggest upset of the tournament so far at Wimbledon. She's the 11th seed to lose so far at SW19, and day two is barely underway. Here are all the top players to go out so far. Seeds out on day one: MEN'S 9th seed Daniil Medvedev 24th seed Stefanos Tsitsipas via retirement 16th seed Francisco Cerundolo 20th seed Alexei Popyrin 8th seed Holger Rune 32nd seed Matteo Berrettini 31st seed Tallon Griekspoor WOMEN'S 20th seed Jelena Ostapenko 32nd seed McCartney Kessler 9th seed Paula Badosa Seeds out on day two: WOMEN'S 3rd seed Jessica Pegula Nick Kyrgios has cheekily suggested that Emma Raducanu is in a 'love triangle' with Carlos Alcaraz and Jack Draper. Raducanu and Alcaraz have been the subject of romance rumours ahead of their upcoming mixed doubles partnership at the US Open, although the British women's No. 1 insists their relationship is purely platonic. Some Alcaraz fans feared that Kyrgios might be trying to muscle in when he left a supportive comment on one of Raducanu's recent Instagram posts. The Aussie, who is working for talkSPORT after being dropped by the BBC, was asked on Tuesday for his take on the obsession with Raducanu's love life. And he jokingly responded: "I don't know, I think it's a love triangle! Draper, Alcaraz, Raducanu. They're fighting over Raducanu I think, I'm not sure." Harriet Dart has partially blamed the heat on her first-round defeat against Dalma Galfi. The British star lost in three sets and argued that the home favourites are not well equipped to deal with the blazing temperatures, which are set to exceed 30 degrees celsius this week. “It was challenging but it's the same for everyone,” she said. “I don't think I've played a match where it was this hot on grass. “We're not very well equipped in this country to deal with it, so it becomes more of a shock. I've played in hotter places but here it's a shock because even when you go inside it's still pretty warm, so you can't escape it. “It was difficult with half the sun on the court and half of it in shade. I was slow to adapt to seeing the ball but she served really well, particularly in big moments.” The daughter of the spectator who was taken ill during Carlos Alcaraz's Wimbledon first-round win against Fabio Fognini has thanked the Spaniard on social media. Alcaraz's five-set victory on Centre Court was suspended during the decider as medical personnel attended to a fan. The reigning two-time champion quickly provided assistance by rushing over with a water bottle before the spectator was guided out of the stands. This morning, the fan's daughter took to social media to show Alcaraz her gratitude after his actions. Eluned Lewis wrote on X: "Thank you @carlosalcaraz for the concern shown to my mum today, who was taken ill during your tennis match at Centre Court @Wimbledon today. Unlikely you'll see this message, but I can try! Thank you @BBCSport." Thank you @carlosalcaraz for the concern shown to my mum today who was taken ill during your tennis match at Centre Court @Wimbledon today. Unlikely you\u2019ll see this message but I can try! Thank you \ud83d\ude4f\u2764\ufe0f @BBCSport Novak Djokovic is about to begin his bid for Wimbledon glory against a tennis star with an unusual sponsorship deal. And while Alexandre Muller insists that his affiliation with OnlyFans is not exactly what it seems, the 28-year-old still refers to himself as 'the sexiest professional tennis player from France'. Muller said in an interview with The Sun: "[OnlyFans] wants to change their image. They are supporting lots of players, golfers, boxers, UFC fighters... a lot of sportsmen. "At the beginning my friends were laughing at me. Then I showed them my platform and they said: ‘OK, it's very cool.' Everybody wants to sign up now. "Do I post risque photos? No, no. I don't do it. Because I don't want to. My job is a tennis player, not making movies for adults. I received a lot of messages, saying: ‘Alex, can you show me this?' But not my body." John McEnroe bluntly described Carlos Alcaraz as looking as 'flat as a pancake' at Wimbledon. Alcaraz made hard work of a five-set victory over Fabio Fognini. McEnroe believes it was a 'wake-up call' for the Spaniard. Speaking on the BBC, the three-time former champion said: “Carlos looked as flat as a pancake. Why? I don't know. Perhaps he assumed this Fognini would fall away pretty quickly. "His serve was off, his forehand… to see him play like that was surprising. You've got to give Fognini credit, but he was up a set and 4-2. He should have won the second set. “He was up 4-2 or 5-3 in the third and he barely pulled that set out. He got blown out in the fourth. It's a good wake-up call for him. He won Queen's, everything was perfect, same as last year. "He won the French Open, pulls out an incredible match [against Jannik Sinner], parties in Ibiza with his buddies, comes to Queen's and almost loses early, but goes on and wins it. Perhaps it's going to be similar here.” We are underway on day two at Wimbledon, with lots of matches getting started at 11am. Great Britain's Heather Watson is currently in action against Denmark's Clara Tauson on BBC Two. Elsewhere, British wildcard Johannus Monday has started his tough test against world No. 13 Tommy Paul. Sonay Kartal successfully sought revenge over 20th seed Jelena Ostapenko at Wimbledon. The British star defeated Ostapenko in three sets, a mere few days after losing to the Latvian in Eastbourne. “I felt great coming into it, so to get that kind of win, I've got masses of confidence,” Kartal said. “I don't think that I could have done too much better at times in that match. I feel like this is the best I've ever played on grass. It's the most confident I've also got in my game. I think I'm in a pretty good spot for round two.” Daniil Medvedev admits he is suffering from a lack of confidence after crashing out of Wimbledon in round one yesterday. The Russian had already exited the Australian Open in the second round and French Open at the first hurdle. And he lost to world No. 64 Benjamin Bonzi in four sets at SW19 to continue his nightmare run. “For me, it's a matter of confidence. If not for the results in Halle, I would be here and say something is definitely missing. It's just a matter of a couple of matches," Medvedev reacted. "This year, I lost a lot of close calls. When I start winning them, I can climb up the rankings. For the moment, I'm not that worried. "If I finish the year ranked somewhere around No. 15 in the world, maybe I'll be more worried. For the moment, I'm not." Yulia Putintseva asked the chair umpire to remove a 'crazy' spectator during her first-round defeat at Wimbledon on Monday. The Kazakhstani was only on court for 44 minutes as she was thrashed 6-0 6-0 by Amanda Anisimova. And she was evidently bothered by someone in the crowd. Putintseva said to the umpire: "Can you take him out because maybe he has a knife, I am not going to continue playing until he leaves. These people are dangerous, they are crazy." An All England Club spokesperson later said: "Following a complaint about the behaviour of a spectator at the match on Court 15, the chair umpire informed security and the matter was dealt with." Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard broke the record for the fastest serve at Wimbledon last night. During his ultimately suspended clash with Taylor Fritz on Court No. 1, the 6ft 8in giant tossed the ball down the court at an astonishing 149mph. That eclipses the previous record of 148pmh set by Taylor Dent in 2010. Carlos Alcaraz and Aryna Sabalenka are the current bookmakers' favourites to triumph in this year's Wimbledon singles, according to Betway. Men's Singles Winner Odds: Carlos Alcaraz – 5/4 Jannik Sinner – 7/4 Novak Djokovic – 5/1 Jack Draper – 12/1 Alexander Zverev – 22/1 Taylor Fritz – 25/1 Alexander Bublik – 33/1 Women's Singles Winner Odds: Aryna Sabalenka – 9/4 Elene Rybakina – 5/1 Coco Gauff – 6/1 Iga Swiatek – 15/2 Mirra Andreeva – 16/1 Marketa Vondrousova – 16/1 Madison Keys – 16/1 Wimbledon have been urged to ditch their strict all-white kit policy. The rules were tightened in the mid 1990s to dictate that all players must wear all-white kit on court, including tracksuits and other clothing. Women have since been told they can wear dark undershorts to prevent anxiety during their menstrual cycles. Billie Jean King believes the 1995 rule change was a "total mistake" and says television viewers struggle to tell players apart during matches. She told the Telegraph: “There's a match that comes on, you sit down, and you look – let's say it's television – who's who? “Tennis people say: ‘Well, the mark is next to their name' [to indicate who is serving]. I shouldn't have to look at a mark, I shouldn't have to look at anything. I should know [who's who]. My sport drives me nuts.” Jack Draper can go all the way and win his first Grand Slam at this year's Wimbledon, claims 1994 champion Conchita Martinez. “He's number four in the world, so he's already there. He's up with the top players," Martinez told BoyleSports. “He's a great guy, and he won the men's title at Indian Wells when Mirra won the women's title, and we saw what he was like practising on the court. He has a great level of focus. “You can tell when a player really wants it. He is very professional. I didn't see him play a lot, but then you pay attention, and he can play on any surface. He is already there; he's beaten top players. “Carlos and Jannik are a bit ahead of Jack. He needs to be consistent the whole year. He needs to be consistent from the baseline to play against these guys. Jack has the game to go to the net and be aggressive, but you're up against two guys who can produce amazing shots. “Jack has a very good chance of making the semi-finals at Wimbledon. Once you get to the semi-finals, why not go all the way? I think Alcaraz will be suitable for Jack's game. He has the potential to go all the way.” Rising British star Oliver Tarvet has theoretically banked £99,000 at Wimbledon this year. But rather harsh circumstances mean the qualifier will not see most of that money following a run that will see him meet Carlos Alcaraz in round two. Tarvet, 21, is the lowest-ranked player in the singles draw at world No. 733. He still attends to San Diego University and intends to complete his final year. His amateur status combined with American college rules mean Tarvet is only allowed to claim £7,290 as his own, in addition to genuine tennis expenses - which will at least allow him to enter more prestige tournaments than before. The rest of the money is paid to his university. Tarvet joked: “I've got to find £60,000 – £70,000 of expenses – tennis is an expensive sport. “I hope to get the prize money and use that money as expenses. I will try and do everything I can to make that work out and to find X amount of expenses so I'm under $10,000 of profit. "[It's] something I've got to figure out. Maybe I will hire someone to help me out with the expenses, make sure the NCAA are happy. It's very important for me. I have a lot of goals at USD still.” Nick Kyrgios has backed Coco Gauff to progress beyond the Wimbledon fourth round for the first time ever this summer. The 21-year-old has two Grand Slams to her name but has never enjoyed a long run in SW19. Kyrgios believes that should change in the coming weeks. "She has an incredible backhand and she's an incredible athlete,” Kyrgios told talkSPORT. “The grass is a little bit faster. It's a faster surface, and I think her forehand swing sometimes can get a bit large on the grass and catch it a bit late. “But you look at some of the results that she's had over the last six months, and I think confidence-wise she's fixed those existing problems on a second serve as well. “She had those problems where she was double-faulting a lot. She had a bit of the yips on a second serve. “So I think she's fixed those, and I think you know serving at Wimbledon is the most important thing. You have to be serving well to win Wimbledon.” It is expected to be another scorching hot day at Wimbledon. Temperatures across London and parts of the south-east of England are forecast to reach as high as 34 degrees celsius. Express Sport explained the rules that are in place when temperatures reach such levels here. And here's a glimpse at the big names in ladies' singles action today... 11am - Elisabetta Cocciaretto vs Jessica Pegula (3) 12.10pm - Karolina Muchova (15) vs Xinyu Wang 12.40pm - Katerina Siniakova vs Qinwen Zheng (5) 1.50pm - Iga Swiatek (8) vs Polina Kudermetova 1.50pm - Mirra Andreeva (7) vs Mayar Sherif 3.20pm - Petra Kvitova vs Emma Navarro (10) 4.40pm - Elina Avanesyan vs Elena Rybakina (11) 5.40pm - Dayana Yastremska vs Coco Gauff (2) Ons Jabeur says she will take a break to ‘disconnect' from tennis after she retired from Wimbledon. The former finalist was in tears as she called for a medical timeout during her match against Viktoriya Tomova. She attempted to continue but eventually retired while trailing 7-6 2-0. "I wasn't expecting not to feel good," said Jabeur. "I've been practising pretty well the last few days but I guess these things happen. I'm really sad. "It doesn't really help me with my confidence and what I keep pushing myself to do, even though it was a very tough season for me. So I hope I'm going to feel better and we'll see what's going to happen. "[I will] definitely try to disconnect a little bit from tennis and try to just enjoy life outside tennis, recover and spend a little bit of time with the family and hopefully that could recharge me. Definitely ‘rest' is the word for it." Here are all the top names to look out for in the men's singles at Wimbledon today... 11am - Alex de Minaur (11) vs Roberto Carballes Baena 11am - Johannus Monday vs Tommy Paul (13) 12.10pm - Nikoloz Basilashvili vs Lorenzo Musetti (7) 1pm - Jannik Sinner (1) vs Luca Nardi 2.40pm (suspended at 1-1) - Arthur Rinderknech vs Alexander Zverev (3) 2.40pm - Taylor Fritz (5) vs Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard 3pm - Ben Shelton (10) vs Alex Bolt 3.50pm - Alexandre Muller vs Novak Djokovic (6) 4.30pm - Jack Draper (4) vs Sebastian Baez John McEnroe has told Fabio Fognini to retire after his defeat against Carlos Alcaraz. Fognini, 38, was playing in his 15th Wimbledon and recently hinted that he was going to step away from the tour. He took two sets from the world No. 2 and was backed by the majority of the Centre Court crowd. "This was the perfect ending for Fognini," McEnroe told the BBC. "Luckily for Alcaraz, towards the end of the fourth set, the crowd realised that Fognini was playing unbelievable. Carlos looked more tired than Fognini even though there's a 16-year age gap! What in the hell is going on here? "So the crowd started rallying behind Alcaraz and that picked him up a little bit. I almost hope that [Fognini] doesn't play anymore because I'm not sure he can play any better than that. "I played [Fognini's wife] Flavio Panetta in seniors mixed doubles at the French [Open] and she thinks it's time for Fabio to be at home more with the kids. I think she is ready for her husband to be home more." Wimbledon could face chaos today with suspended matches added to the updated order of play. Several matches were halted before the 11pm curfew last night, including those involving Alexander Zverev and Taylor Fritz. Those matches have been added to their respective courts in the second slot of the day. It leaves bosses with a potential headache as some courts are set to host up to five matches. Centre Court will have four ties, the same as yesterday. Court No. 3 will host five. Novak Djokovic has been given a brutal reality check ahead of his Wimbledon campaign. It is widely accepted that Wimbledon provides the Serb's final opportunity to land a coveted 25th Grand Slam title. But former tennis star Feliciano Lopez says Djokovic is not on the same level as rivals Carlos Alcaraz and Jannik Sinner anymore. “He's not at the levels of Carlos and Jannik, especially in the last 18 months, because the numbers speak for themselves,” the three-time Wimbledon quarter-finalist told Sky Sports. “Although the gap is still big, I see the grass as the only place for him to get to this level that they play because the grass is very different. “Djokovic proved that he can still compete at this level but he will have a better chance on grass.” Taylor Fritz fumed at a Wimbledon umpire after his match was suspended at around 10.20pm yesterday. Wimbledon's curfew is not until 11pm but Fritz's clash with Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard was halted 40 minutes prior. The American had just battled back to win the fourth set and send the match into a deciding set. To a chorus of boos, Fritz ranted at the umpire, believing there was more than enough time for a final set to take place. Their match will resumed today. Never at Wimbledon have seven Brits all won on the same day. It is testament to the strength of the British game that the country has so many top players in the first round this year. Katie Boulter saw off ninth seed Paula Badosa on Centre Court, while Emma Raducanu defeated Mimi Xu in an all-British clash. Sonay Kartal beat 20th-seed Jelena Ostapenko in immediate revenge for her Eastbourne loss. Oliver Tarvet continued his remarkable as a qualifier, winning as the No. 733-ranked player in the world. Arthur Fery, Cam Norrie and Billy Harris all progressed. Hello and welcome back to Express Sport's coverage of Wimbledon. We'll have regular updates throughout the day as the second halves of the first-round matches are played. Stay tuned... Alexander Zverev will head into day two of Wimbledon on a level playing field with Arthur Rinderknech. The German wins a second-set tiebreak before play is suspended for the night ahead of the 11pm curfew. The two players will resume their first-round battle tomorrow with everything still to play for. Former tennis star Todd Woodbridge believes that Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard should be over the moon with the decision to suspend his Wimbledon first-round clash with Taylor Fritz. The big-serving Frenchman had just lost two sets on the bounce when match officials opted to call it off and pick it back up tomorrow with the 11pm curfew closing in. With the scores at two sets apiece, Woodbridge said: "I'm a little surprised by that decision. I think the referee has come out too early, he could've given them the option. We still had 45 minutes to go to curfew. "The sets that we had have all been under 45 minutes, they've been close to it but there was definitely the chance of an outcome there tonight. "I think Mpetshi Perricard, good for him, he should get off and be very happy with that. Taylor Fritz will be a little annoyed by that decision I have no doubt because he played an exceptional tiebreak from 5-1 down to hang in." The match between Taylor Fritz and Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard has been suspended for the night in bizarre fashion. It caused frustration in the crowd, with many fans booing the announcement which came 40 minutes before the 11pm curfew. Fritz, who had just edged a fourth-set tiebreak to force a deciding set, was also left raging with the decision. He was well within his rights to be upset, given that there would probably have been enough time for the match to reach a conclusion. Spare a thought for the paying ticket-holders who have seemingly been denied the full value of their money. Holger Rune was left frustrated after throwing away a two-set lead against Nicolas Jarry earlier today. The Dane was in control until the return of a troublesome knee injury saw him slip to a 4-6 4-6 7-5 6-3 6-4 loss. After the match, Rune had some interesting words for Jarry while discussing his defeat. He said: "If I play normal, I'm beating him nine out of ten times, with all respect for Nicolas Jarry. "I'm going to check now with the head doctor and physio and will take it from there. "I don't know if it's worse now, or better, or the same. It needs to be examined." Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard broke a long-standing Wimbledon record during his match against Taylor Fritz. The towering Frenchman, who stands at six feet and eight inches tall, pulled off thunderous services of 151mph and 153mph. It saw him surpass the previous benchmark of 148mph, which was set by Taylor Dent back in 2010. Mpetshi Perricard currently leads Fritz by two sets to one, with his American opponent battling to avoid an early exit. John McEnroe wants Fabio Fognini to retire following his spirited defeat to Carlos Alcaraz on Monday. The Italian is in the midst of his final season as a professional and McEnroe thinks that his last outing at Wimbledon would be the ideal note on which to end his career. "This was the perfect ending for Fognini," the American told the BBC. "Luckily for Alcaraz, towards the end of the fourth set, the crowd realised that Fognini was playing unbelievable. Carlos looked more tired than Fognini even though there's a 16-year age gap! What in the hell is going on here? "So the crowd started rallying behind Alcaraz and that picked him up a little bit. I almost hope that [Fognini] doesn't play anymore because I'm not sure he can play any better than that. "I played [Fognini's wife] Flavio Panetta in seniors mixed doubles at the French [Open] and she thinks it's time for Fabio to be at home more with the kids. I think she is ready for her husband to be home more." Play on the outdoor courts has been suspended for poor light. Botic van de Zandschulp led Matteo Arnaldi by two tiebreak sets on Court 12 when they had to stop. And Shintaro Mochizuki had just forced a fifth and final set against Giulio Zeppieri when their match was abandoned for the night. With seven wins in the singles, it has been the most successful day for British players at Wimbledon in the Open era. As well as Boulter, there were victories for Cameron Norrie, Arthur Fery, Sonay Kartal, Emma Raducanu, Oliver Tarvet and Billy Harris. Some of those were huge upsets and it remains to be seen how the British contingent will fare in the second round. There has been ANOTHER huge upset at Wimbledon and this time it's courtesy of Katie Boulter. She beats Paula Badosa in three sets to become the seventh Briton to reach the second round. It's been a brilliant opening day for the home contingent and Boulter looks delighted after securing her own surprise victory. She will go up against Solana Sierra in her next match on Wednesday. Nick Kyrgios was spotted in Naomi Osaka's box to watch her beat Talia Gibson earlier today. The outspoken Aussie is due to link up with Osaka in the mixed doubles tournament at the US Open later this year. He would have been impressed with the relatively straightforward manner of her 6-4 7-6 victory on Court 18. Nick Kyrgios was in Naomi Osaka\u2019s box for her first round match at Wimbledon. \ud83d\udc40 pic.twitter.com/7QV7iE05wl Yulia Putintseva suffered a humbling fall from grace just under 12 months after her barnstorming Wimbledon win over Iga Swiatek. The only positive she can take is that the suffering didn't last long, as her bid for glory at SW19 was ended in just 43 minutes by Amanda Anisimova. Putintseva went on the best Wimbledon run of her career in 2024. Her march to the round of 16 included big wins over 27th seed Katerina Siniakova in round two and top seed Swiatek in round three. But this grass-court season has been considerably less successful. With only 30 per cent of points won on her first serve and zero break point opportunities in the entire match, Putintseva was thrashed 6-0 6-0 by 13th seed Anisimova in a one-sided mauling on Court 15. And she didn't take it especially well. During a changeover, Putintseva was seen sobbing into her towel with both hands covering her face as the crowd watched on. No. 5 seed Qinwen Zheng's first-round match against Katerina Siniakova has been cancelled. They were due to play fourth on Court 3 but play has run over, as former finalist and 32nd seed Matteo Berrettini is locked in battle with Kamil Majchrzak. There was an almighty cheer on Court 1 after Emma Raducanu's victory, as the fans were informed they were getting a fourth bonus match - Taylor Fritz vs Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard. And the roof was closed on Wimbledon's second-biggest showcourt before the tall, big-servers took to the stage. It's almost 8pm and the light and visibility will soon become an issue - especially on Centre and 1 which are surrounded by a bowl-like structure. And organisers decided to shut the Court 1 roof before the match started so they could turn on the floodlights. We could have a similar scenario on Centre - Boulter vs Badosa still isn't done and the Zverev vs Rinderknech match is due after. Paula Badosa is hitting her stride against Katie Boulter, with the Spaniard having just taken the second set. It means a decider will be required to split the two players on Centre Court. The momentum is with the ninth seed and Boulter will need to dig deep to turn things around. Emma Raducanu was in a jovial mood after beating Mingge Xu to reach the second round. The match was briefly disrupted when a fan in the stands popped open a bottle of champagne and the cork went flying over her head. Raducanu thought it was hilarious and went over to pick up the cork, waving it in the air and offering it back to the spectators. Reflecting on the incident in her post-match interview, the young Brit said: "I'm glad people were having fun today. "I saw a champagne cork fly onto the court so that was fun, glad you guys are having a good time, cheers to you." Katie Boulter has just stormed into the lead against ninth seed Paula Badosa. The first set has gone the way of the Brit, who is halfway to pulling off another Wimbledon upset. She is aiming to become the seventh home player to book a place in the next round. Emma Raducanu makes the perfect start to her Wimbledon campaign with a routine victory over Mingge Xu. The former US Open champion secures a 6-3 6-3 triumph, having been on top for the duration of the contest. Katie Boulter, meanwhile, has just broken Paula Badosa in the early stages of their match over on Centre Court. Carlos Alcaraz paid a touching tribute to Fabio Fognini after knocking him out of what looks to be his final Wimbledon. The Spaniard was pushed all the way by the Italian veteran in an entertaining five-set thriller on Monday afternoon. "I don't know why it's his last Wimbledon, because the level he is playing, he can still play for three or four more years," said Alcaraz. "I have to give him the credit for such a great match. "Fabio is a great player. He has shown his level and talent over his whole career. I'm just a little bit sad that it's probably his last Wimbledon but I'm happy to have shared the court and the locker room with him, and we are going to enjoy the last of him." Carlos Alcaraz is safely through to the second round after a titanic battle with Fabio Fognini. He wins the decisive fifth set after a 15-minute delay for a medical emergency in the crowd. The final score is 7-5 6-7 7-5 2-6 6-1 in favour of the reigning Wimbledon champion. He will face either Dan Evans or Jay Clarke in the second round later this week. Emma Raducanu is already a set up against Mingge Xu on Court One. The former US Open champion is looking strong and will be hoping to close out the match without being taken the distance. Carlos Alcaraz's match with Fabio Fognini has been stopped due to a medical emergency in the crowd. Play was paused as the umpire announced a break of play after Alcaraz went into his bag to grab a bottle of water and give it to the person involved. The umpire said: "Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately there has been an incident with a spectator. Health and safety is our priority. We will be pausing the match." What is happening to Carlos Alcaraz!? He loses the fourth set with a whimper as Fabio Fognini regains the upper hand. This certainly wasn't in the script for the defending champion. He looks all over the place and needs to find a solution quickly. It's going the distance on Centre Court. Emma Raducanu's first-round match against British teenage wildcard Mimi Xu is about to start on Court 1. There's an excited chatter around Wimbledon's second showcourt as the Brits take to the stage. You can follow live score updates here. Joao Fonseca apologised for beating British star Jacob Fearnley on Court 1. "I'm sorry, winning against a British guy but thanks a lot for the support here," Fonseca said. "Thanks for respecting the tennis today. Jacob is a great friend and great player. I am looking forward to the next meeting against him." He added: "At the beginning of the match both of us were very nervous. We were just making serves and there were no rallies. Very nervous." There's been another huge upset in the men's singles draw. No. 8 seed Holger Rune suffered defeat at the hands of qualifier Nicolas Jarry after leading by two sets to love. But former world No.16 Jarry, whose ranking has slipped outside the top 140, stormed back to win 4-6 4-6 7-5 6-3 6-4. Rune is the second top-10 ATP star to lose on Monday after Daniil Medvedev was stunned by Benjamin Bonzi. Jacob Fearnley is out of Wimbledon after losing at the hands of Joao Fonseca. It ends 6-4 6-1 7-6 in favour of the Brazilian teenager on Court One. Emma Raducanu is next up against Mingge Xu and you can follow game-by-game updates via our dedicated match blog. Carlos Alcaraz breaks Fabio Fognini to win the third set on Centre Court. The young Spaniard is now just one set away from reaching the second round. Fognini is throwing everything at the reigning Wimbledon champion and can still go the distance if he takes the fourth set. Alcaraz, however, has the momentum back on his side and will be hugely difficult to stop. Stefanos Tsitsipas has suggested that he could retire from tennis after being forced to withdraw from Wimbledon due to injury. Earlier today, he retired from his opening match against Valentin Royer after the end of the second set. Tsitsipas has since opened up on his injury problems in a heartbreaking press conference. He said: "I feel like I'm left without answers. I don't know. I've tried everything. "It's probably the most difficult situation that I've ever been faced with, because it's an ongoing issue that doesn't seem to be disappearing or fading off as much. "Myself, as a person, I have a limit at some point, so I'll definitely have to have my final answer on whether I want to do stuff or not in the next couple of months. "This is going to be hard, but if I see it going in that trajectory, there is no point at competing." Arthur Fery pulls off another Wimbledon shock by securing a 6-4 6-1 4-6 6-4 victory over Alexei Popyrin. Fery, who is ranked outside the world's top 400, had never won a tour-level match before today. It is arguably the biggest surprise of the day, coming just hours after Sonay Kartal dumped out Jelena Ostapenko. Fery will face either Roman Safiullin or Luciano Darderi in the second round on Wednesday. Fabio Fognini prevails in a tiebreak to claim the second set in his match against Carlos Alcaraz. The experienced Italian is producing some fine tennis, which is making his Spanish rival work hard. He has momentum on his side but will need to keep it up to spring a surprise against the defending champion. You can follow game-by-game updates via our dedicated match blog. Joao Fonseca is a set up against Jacob Fearnley here on Court 1. The Brit hasn't been able to find his serve and gave away five double faults to trail 6-4. Fonseca win the final game on Fernley's serve to love. Sir Gareth Southgate and Sir David Beckham are both in the royal box today, fresh from receiving their honours at Buckingham Palace. They watched on as Carlos Alcaraz played Fabio Fognini. Oliver Tarvet will be unable to claim the majority of his £99,000 prize for reaching the second round. He attends university in the United States and the rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) require athletes to stay amateur. Tarvet is able to claim up to £7,282 in expenses as well as the expenses he has incurred during the tournament. However, it means the young Brit will miss out on the vast majority of his Wimbledon payout, which will go to his university. Fabio Fognini smacked his racket on the floor after being broken by Carlos Alcaraz in the second set. The Italian shouted in anger after losing his serve and hit his racket multiple times in frustration. Aryna Sabalenka was delighted with her first-round win over Carson Branstine. Walking down the tunnel, she clenched her fist and said "vamos, vamos, vamos" at an official holding a camera. Jacob Fearnley has the lion's share of support here inside Court 1. There is the odd 'come on Fonseca' being screamed from the stands but every point Fearnley wins drowns it out. Another seed goes down as Stefanos Tsitsipas retires while trailing Valentin Royer 6-3 6-2. He called the physio during the second set and played on. But after losing it 6-2, the 24th seed appeared to be asking Goran Ivanisevic whether he should continue, then told the umpire he was done. It's Royer's first-ever tour-level match win. I've just taken my place on Court 1 for Jacob Fearnley vs Joao Fonseca. I'm tipping this to be the match of the day. Two rising stars have shown plenty of promise so far in 2025. The big question is how many Brazilian fans will have tickets to this area that is basking in the south west London sun. Fonseca's followers travel in their numbers and are known to make quite the noise... No. 24 seed Stefanos Tsitsipas is in trouble. The two-time Grand Slam finalist is a set and double-break down to qualifier Valentin Royer and has called the physio. He's receiving an on-court medical time-out on his back as new coach Goran Ivanisevic watches on from his box. Ninth seed Daniil Medvedev - who has reached the semi-final here for two years running - has suffered a huge upset in the first round. World No. 64 Benjamin Bonzi stunned the former No. 1 7-6(2) 3-6 7-6(3) 6-2 on Court 2, handing Medvedev his first-ever opening-round loss at Wimbledon, and went to embrace his team, who had been watching courtside. Bonzi said: "This is special for me today. This is my first top-10 win in a Slam, obviously it's always special in this tournament, the atmosphere, all the colours, the grass, the green. "I love this place so it's very special, Daniil is a great player, he did two semi-finals so I knew it was a tough match but sometimes it's better to play this kind of player in the first round, anything can happen. So I'm very happy." Asked how he could be so calm, he replied: "I'm pretty focusing to speak English right now! But one more time this is a great place to play tennis. "I have maybe 20 people in my box so I'm really enjoying time here, I knew I can do something big today, it was maybe my day but I'm enjoying a lot." Fabio Fognini is exchanging games with Carlos Alcaraz on Centre Court. He appeared to stretch out his hamstring after the opening point of the match but seems perfectly comfortable now. Fancy taking a closer look at Carlos Alcaraz's battle with Fabio Fognini on Centre Court? Follow our game-by-game updates here Wildcard Oliver Crawford became the first Brit to lose a singles match at Wimbledon this year. The world No. 248 too the first set over Italian star Mattia Bellucci but went out 6-7(3) 6-4 6-4. It's been a successful day for the Brits otherwise so far, with Sonay Kartal and Oliver Tarvet winning. Daniil Medvedev is on the brink of an early exit at Wimbledon as he is 2-1 behind and a break down in the fourth set against Benjamin Bonzi. The 2021 US Open winner has reached the semi-finals at the All England Club in each of the last two years but will be sent packing unless he turns the match around quickly. Sonay Kartal beat 20th seed Jelena Ostapenko. The British star said afterwards: “Yeah I would say that was by far one of the toughest matches I've played, I struggle against the big hitters so to be able to get that win today after she beat me easily last week. I appreciate you guys coming out, when I needed it the most, you guys were there. “After the year I had last year, I made a big conscious effort this year to play the bigger matches, to put myself under the most pressure I could on the court. I knew that maybe I wouldn't get the results straight away but eventually it would pay off and it did today. “This tournament last year was probably the best tournament I've ever had and my most favourite. I left here last year feeling a much more confident player on and off the court. I knew my level was there, just eventually had to force it out of myself. This whole year I feel like I'm playing better, I'm improving each week. I want to see how far I can go this week.” Oliver Tarvet has admitted he is overjoyed after defeating Leandro Riedi in the first round of Wimbledon. “There's a lot of emotions,” explained the 21-year-old Briton. “I'm just really overjoyed to be in this situation you know. All of the hard work I've put in in the last few years has clearly paid off. “I was just taking it match by match, just trying to see what I could do. Obviously it was my first Tour-level event and then to come out here, come through qualifying and also win in the first round at Wimbledon and have a chance to play maybe Carlos [Alcaraz] on Wednesday is just truly incredible. “It's a dream come true for me to play here. It's really special. You work for these types of moments, you work to play on the most prestigious court in the world. It's just really special and I'm really thankful for everyone.” It's a red-hot day at Wimbledon, as you may have heard. The temperature on Centre Court right now is 30 degrees Celsius and it's only going to get hotter as the afternoon wears on. Carlos Alcaraz and Fabio Fognini are first up - the firm favourite will be keen to wrap it up swiftly and get back under the AC. Oliver Tarvet has seen out the match against Leandro Riedi and has booked his place in the second round after securing a 6-4, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Swiss ace. It's been a good day for the Britons so far, and Tarvet will join Sonay Kartal in the second round following her victory over Jelena Ostapenko. Oliver Tarvet is about to serve for the match against Riedi. He leads 6-4 6-4 5-4. Ons Jabeur has said that she didn't expect to feel bad on the court after retiring from her first-round match at Wimbledon. The two-time runner-up here broke down in tears 26 minutes into the match then took a medical time out but continued playing. She was trailing Viktoriya Tomova 7-6 2-0 when she threw in the towel. Jabeur later said: “Yeah I mean I wasn't expecting not to feel good. I've been practising pretty well the last few days but I guess these things happen and yeah, I'm pretty sad. Doesn't really help me with my confidence and what I keep pushing myself to do even though it was a very tough season for me. So yeah, I hope I can feel better and see what's going to happen.” As for what she'll do next, she added: “Definitely try to disconnect a little bit from tennis and try to just enjoy life outside tennis. Recover and spend a little bit of time with the family and hopefully that can recharge me. Otherwise, I don't know, I will try to definitely rest is the word for it.” Sonay Kartal became the first Brit to win a match at Wimbledon this year, upsetting 20th seed and former French Open champion Jelena Ostapenko 7-5 2-6 6-2. Ostapenko beat Kartal just six days ago in Eastbourne but the world No.51 got her revenge and said: “I would say that was by far one of the toughest matches I've played, I struggle against the big hitters so to be able to get that win today after she beat me easily last week. I appreciate you guys coming out, when I needed it the most, you guys were there.” Kartal reached the third round here as a qualifier ranked down at No. 298 in the world. She will now face world No. 111 Viktoriya Tomova in round two. Daniil Medvedev has struck back against unseeded Frenchman Benjamin Bonzi by taking the second set 6-3. The 29-year-old is aiming to turn the match around after losing the first set on a tiebreak. But he's a break down in the third set. Medvedev reached back-to-back semi-finals at the All England Club in 2023 and 2024 and won the US Open in 2021. Novak Djokovic accepts that Wimbledon could be his final chance to land a 25th Grand Slam title. Djokovic's 24 majors is a men's singles record, but the competitive Serb is determined to win more. He has won seven of those titles at Wimbledon and believes the grass courts are his best chance of adding to his tally. Djokovic said: “I would probably agree that Wimbledon could be the best chance because of the results I had, because of how I feel, how I play at Wimbledon, just getting that extra push mentally and motivation to perform the best tennis at the highest level.” Two-time finalist Ons Jabeur has retired from her opening match against Viktoriya Tomova. Former world No. 2 Jabeur broke down in tears just 26 minutes into the first set and needed a medical time out but continued playing and lost it in a tiebreak. She threw in the towel with Tomova leading 7-6(5) 2-0. Ninth seed and two-time semi-finalist Daniil Medvedev is in trouble. The former world No. 1 has lost the first set of his match to Benjamin Bonzi on Court 2, 7-2 in the tiebreak. Two-time Wimbledon semi-finalist Elina Svitolina became the first winner of this year's Championships. The 14th seed beat Anna Bondar 6-3 6-1 on Court 18. Oliver Crawford has joined Brits Sonay Kartal and Oliver Tarvet in going a set up at Wimbledon. Crawford, the world No. 248, is up against Mattia Bellucci. Famous faces have flocked to Wimbledon on day one of the tournament - although some are more familiar than others. Celeb spotters will not have had too much trouble recognising David Beckham in a recent Instagram post, but the one-time Wimbledon champion he was smiling alongside may have caught a few others out. Former Manchester United, Real Madrid and England icon Beckham is a regular attendee at the All England Club. He has therefore done plenty of mingling with some of the biggest names in tennis, and one player he seems to have struck up a bond with is five-time Grand Slam champion Maria Sharapova. Sharapova grinned from ear to ear as she sat alongside Beckham for a wholesome photo posted to her Instagram account, which was accompanied by the caption: "Let the (Wimbledon) games begin". But she looked completely different from the leggy, blond-haired sports superstar fans came to know during her 19-year playing career. Now, at 38 years old, Sharapova has ditched the light-coloured locks for shorter and darker hair, and the difference is striking. With day one of Wimbledon now fully underway, the fans around the grounds will be flocking to the bars to enjoy a drink in the sunshine. But they'll need to dig into their pockets, with pints of Stella costing £8.85 while Pimm's is £12.25 a cup, and there's a top-line wine on offer in one restaurant for £217.50. Briton Oliver Tarvet was forced to come through qualifying to reach the Wimbledon main draw but has clinched the first set against Swiss opponent Leandro Riedi after winning it 6-4. Fellow Briton Sonay Kartal, meanwhile, has won the first set 7-5 against 20th seed Jelena Ostapenko after fighting off set points and battling back from a break down. Could we be in for a memorable opening day for the home favourites? Ons Jabeur called for a medical time-out in her match against Viktoriya Tomova. Jabeur was in tears as she waited to have her vitals checked by a doctor. She has returned to the court but is 3-2 down in the first set. Aryna Sabalenka, who is the favourite to win the ladies' singles title this year, will take on Canadian model Carson Branstine in her opening match today. The showdown will be played on No. 1 Court at 1pm. Branstine, who is currently ranked at No. 194 in the world, told CLAY: “I love being in front of a camera during a photoshoot. It's fun - I love fashion. It has been one of the reasons why I have been able to afford some trips. I didn't want to ask my parents for anything, I wanted everything to come from me and my tennis.” She then boasted: “I would say that I am one of the best athletes on the circuit. I'm confident in that - I run fast, lift a lot of weight and I'm quite agile for how tall I am.” Pablo Carreno Busta has withdrawn from Wimbledon. The Spaniard was due to face Chris Rodesch in the first round. It is unclear why he has withdrawn from the tournament. Lucky loser Cristian Garin of Chile will take Carreno Busta's place in the first round. There will be a host of star players to look out for on the outside courts today. Two-time Grand Slam finalist Stefanos Tsitsipas will be in action on Court 12 after Frances Tiafoe makes an appearance on the same court. And Leylah Fernandez, who lost to Emma Raducanu in the 2021 US Open final, will also feature on Court 12. Two-time Wimbledon finalist Ons Jabeur will play on Court 14, with former Canadian Open champion Alexei Popyrin appearing on Court 15. Meanwhile, Jiri Lehecka, who defeated Jack Draper in the Queen's semi-finals, will play his first round match on Court 17. Elsewhere, Cameron Norrie is on Court 18 and will take on Roberto Bautista Agut. Two-time Wimbledon champion Petra Kvitova will play at the All England Club for the final time at this year's tournament. Kvitova was the women's singles champion in 2011 and 2014. The 35-year-old faces 10th seed Emma Navarro in the first round. "It´ll be amazing, for sure. It´s my favorite tournament. It always has been and it always will be. So it´ll be very nice to be back," Kvitova told The Associated Press. "It´s always brought me so many memories. Some really good memories, of course. But also bad memories, because losing with the pressure there is hard. “Even with the two best results of my career, I do feel like sometimes the losses were very, very painful. But at the end of the day, winning two titles is what counts the most." For the first time in the Open Era, the iconic sight of Wimbledon's line judges taking their positions will not be part of this year's tournament. Rules and regulations have been brought in line with every other ATP Tour event, and most WTA Tour events, which now use electronic line calling. All 18 courts will use the technology, which features an automated 'out' call. Players will be unable to challenge decisions as they have done in previous years. Tennis -playing friends Linda, 62, and Aleta, 46, were the first on the scene but a few hours later queue experts Vicki and Nigel Broad from Neath in South Wales rocked up. They all got chatting and once Linda and Aleta realised they were talking to seasoned Wimbledon queue experts in Vicki and Nigel they allowed the Brit pair to pitch their tent first. Linda, who plays tennis with Aleta in a tennis team called Hotshots in Houston, explained: "We just don't want to be first so we let them go ahead." While Linda admitted this was actually a bit of a tactic for them to avoid the full glare of media scrutiny on Monday morning, they were also happy to let some Brits be first in line in the 10,000 strong queue. Read more here The queue is officially shut. Wimbledon CEO Sally Bolton has confirmed that the queue was closed around an hour ago due to it being at capacity. Jannik Sinner has refused to explain why he sacked two members of his team on the eve of Wimbledon. The world No. 1 dismissed fitness coach Marco Panichi and physiotherapist Ulises Badio. Both men were replacements for staff fired in the aftermath of Sinner's doping case, for which he voluntarily served a three-month ban. No reason has been given for the departures of Panichi and Badio. Sinner said: “Nothing seriously bad happened. They did great work for three months. “Sometimes, things happen. The timing obviously isn't the best, but having done a lot of work before, it won't affect this Grand Slam a lot. I feel well physically and mentally and ready to compete.” There will be plenty of big-hitters on No. 2 Court as well today, with Daniil Medvedev, Madison Keys and Jasmine Paolini all in action. 11am | Benjamin Bonzi vs Daniil Medvedev | Men's singles Estimated 1pm | Elena-Gabriela Ruse vs Madison Keys | Ladies' singles Estimated 2.30pm | Jasmine Paolini vs Anastasija Sevastova | Ladies' singles Estimated 4pm | Taylor Fritz vs Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard | Men's singles Wimbledon village has been buzzing all morning. Waiting staff were rushed off their feet as tennis fans flocked to SW19 well before the gates open at 10am. The Ivy in particular was packed out with staff donning green blazers. I spoke to one gentleman on the way down to the All England CLub who had his queue card. He arrived at 4.55am and was position 3,800. He's hoping to get a groundspass. Emma Raducanu's stalker was blocked from gaining entry to Wimbledon this week. Ahead of the tournament, alarm bells were raised by the system that deals with the ticket ballot. A man who had followed Raducanu to events in Asia earlier this year, before handing her a letter and a signed photo, had attempted to purchase tickets through the ballot. The name of the man - which has never been revealed to the public after he was given a restraining order by Dubai police - was black-listed by the tournament's system and he will not be on the grounds over the next fortnight. Raducanu told the BBC last week: “When I heard that, my thoughts were that everyone at Wimbledon had done an amazing job. I got a notification and the police contacted me, they assured me everything was okay. "I know that I'm not the first athlete to go through this and I probably won't be the last. Not just athlete, female in general. It's just something that maybe we all have to deal with at some point. I feel okay, I feel comfortable, I feel safe. I've had great protection whenever I've been at these events. “At the tournaments, I have a lot more protection around me, especially the ones here in the UK, where there are most spectators around. I feel a difference and that reassures me, it makes me feel more comfortable.” Raducanu faces British rising star Mimi Xu, 17, in the first round today. Their match takes place on Court No. 1. Aryna Sabalenka is first up on No. 1 Court today, with three Britons in action afterwards. 1pm | Aryna Sabalenka vs Carson Branstine | Ladies' singles Estimated 3pm | Jacob Fearnley vs Joao Fonseca | Men's singles Estimated 6pm | Emma Raducanu vs Mimi Xu | Ladies' singles Wimbledon could be set for its hottest ever temperatures this week as a heatwave hits the south and east of England. Temperatures could rise as high as 34 degrees celsius in parts of the country on Monday. On Tuesday, parts of south-east England could then hit 35, according to forecaster Matthew Lenhart. Since 1960, UK temperatures in June have only exceeded 34 degrees three times. Last summer's tournament was disrupted by rain during the earlier rounds. Carlos Alcaraz will get the Centre Court action underway this year as the defending men's champion. Briton Katie Boulter and German star Alexander Zverev will also be in action on the show court. 1.30pm | Fabio Fognini vs Carlos Alcaraz | Men's singles Estimated 3.30pm | Paula Badosa vs Katie Boulter | Ladies' singles Estimated 5pm | Arthur Rinderknech vs Alexander Zverev | Men's singles Avocado enjoyers will be left disappointed in SW19 over the next fortnight. In a bid to go greener than the courts, the popular fruit has reportedly been taken off the menu. According to The Times, avocado has been replaced by crushed peas in a bold choice. In addition, 30 of the 42 kitchens on site will not use gas. The showers used by players will be heated by solar thermal tubes. Wimbledon fans reportedly walked out of the queue yesterday as the weather was too hot for them. Stewards revealed to The Telegraph that fans had been leaving Wimbledon Park, where the queue starts, and telling them they would return when the weather was cooler. It is forecast to hit 36 degrees Celsius at Wimbledon today, with the record temperature recorded during The Championships coming a decade ago as the temperature peaked at 35.7 degrees Celsius. UK health officials have issued an amber heat health warning until 6pm tomorrow for the majority of the country, including Wimbledon. Fabio Fognini banned his young son from speaking with Carlos Alcaraz at Wimbledon. The veteran Italian will play Alcaraz in what could be his final Wimbledon appearance. His entire family have flown to London this week to watch the match. “Obviously, with these guys, there's little to think about,” Fognini told AS, reacting to the draw. “Two days ago, when the draw came out, my son called me and said, 'Dad, see, you're playing against Carlitos'. And I said, 'Yes, do you want to come?'. "[He said] 'Yes, yes, yes, I'm coming, I'm coming'. And [my wife] Flavia, also with the little girl, is coming to watch the game. Now, when [my eldest son] saw him, I told him, 'Don't say hello to him, because he's my opponent tomorrow', and he got angry.” Reigning men's champion Carlos Alcaraz has revealed that he has linked up with Andy Murray for a game of golf. Murray, who won the Wimbledon title on two occasions in his career, worked as Novak Djokovic's coach for a spell at the start of the year but ultimately left the veteran's team. When asked about how he prepares for Grand Slam tournaments ahead of Wimbledon, the Spaniard said: “I play some golf. Actually, I play with Andy Murray on Monday and a few more players.” He added: “Just went to the centre a little bit. Just wanted to go to the centre a little bit, walk around, have good food, and just having quality time with them doing some stuff that probably I wouldn't be able to do it while the tournament is on.” Wimbledon chiefs will implement a rare rule due to the sizzling temperatures at the All England Club. The rule, which will come into force if temperatures go beyond 30.1 degrees Celsius, will allow a 10-minute pause between the third and fourth set of men's matches, or between sets two and three of women's matches. And outlining the new heat regulations, Wimbledon referee Denise Parnell said: “The heat rule will apply to all singles events at the qualifying and main draw for The Championships 2025. “It applies to all matches including those which have already started. Only one of the players participating in the match needs to request the break for the rule to be implemented.” Emma Raducanu has talked down her chances of success at Wimbledon after admitting she received some “pretty bad news” in the lead up to the tournament. The 22-year-old Briton explained in her pre-tournament press conference: “Truthfully, I don't expect much from myself this year. I know I've just been dealing with certain things. I just want to go out there and embrace the moment. I want to embrace the occasion. “I know there's not many opportunities to be playing at Wimbledon. You get it once a year and for a finite amount of time. I'm just looking forward to going out there and feeling the surroundings and the atmosphere.” Good morning and welcome to the Express Sport live Wimbledon blog on day one of The Championships. It's set to be a scorcher at the All England Club today, with some of the best tennis players in the world in action a little later. So grab a coffee and stick with us throughout the day for live updates. EXPRESS.CO.UK Daily Express uses notifications to keep you updated
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Tommy Paul watched entire Carlos Alcaraz-Jannik Sinner Roland Garros final on his phone
Source: Tennis.com    Published: 2025-07-01 16:30:00

The American talked the widening gap between the Top 2 and the field after winning at SW19.ByDavid KanePublished Jul 01, 2025 copy_link Published Jul 01, 2025 Tommy Paul has been known to enjoy a classic match from years past, but the American got to see one play out in real time when he spent a Sunday watching Carlos Alcaraz beat Jannik Sinner for the Roland Garros title—all from the comfort of his phone.“I do love watching tennis while I'm in the tournament,” Paul told Steve Weissman and Jon Wertheim in his visit to the Tennis Channel Live Desk following a first-round Wimbledon win over Johannus Monday. “When I'm out of the tournament, I don't usually watch a lot. But I didn't miss that one. I was at my girlfriend's Polo event and watching on my phone. It was an unbelievable match.“I started watching it when I woke up and then five hours later I was still on my phone watching it.” “I do love watching tennis while I'm in the tournament,” Paul told Steve Weissman and Jon Wertheim in his visit to the Tennis Channel Live Desk following a first-round Wimbledon win over Johannus Monday. “When I'm out of the tournament, I don't usually watch a lot. But I didn't miss that one. I was at my girlfriend's Polo event and watching on my phone. It was an unbelievable match.“I started watching it when I woke up and then five hours later I was still on my phone watching it.” “I started watching it when I woke up and then five hours later I was still on my phone watching it.” Paul had played Alcaraz in the quarterfinals and, hindered by injury, managed just four games against the eventual champion. Asked about the state of the ATP field the American admitted that, even at his best, Alcaraz and Sinner are currently the toughest outs in tennis.“I think right now those guys are a level above everyone else,” said Paul, Wimbledon's No. 13 seed. “People have a lot of catching up to do. These guys are dominating when it comes to the Slams. These are the tournaments everyone wants to do the best in, and they're three out of five set matches. In best three out of five, I feel like the better player comes out on top most of the time, and they seem to be coming out on top every time. It shows that the people right below them really have to gain a level to be competing with them in these events.“Last year here against Carlos, I feel like I picked my level up in the opening set and at some point you feel like Carlos took it to another level and I couldn't stay there with him. He played so fast. It kind of feels like he's got constant pressure on you the entire time and you can't hit one ball that's without a ton of quality or he's on top of you, attacking the net. Same with Sinner. Sinner absolutely pounds the ball. If you don't play deep in the court and hit the ball hard, he's on offense and you definitely don't want to be on defense with those guys.” “I think right now those guys are a level above everyone else,” said Paul, Wimbledon's No. 13 seed. “People have a lot of catching up to do. These guys are dominating when it comes to the Slams. These are the tournaments everyone wants to do the best in, and they're three out of five set matches. In best three out of five, I feel like the better player comes out on top most of the time, and they seem to be coming out on top every time. It shows that the people right below them really have to gain a level to be competing with them in these events.“Last year here against Carlos, I feel like I picked my level up in the opening set and at some point you feel like Carlos took it to another level and I couldn't stay there with him. He played so fast. It kind of feels like he's got constant pressure on you the entire time and you can't hit one ball that's without a ton of quality or he's on top of you, attacking the net. Same with Sinner. Sinner absolutely pounds the ball. If you don't play deep in the court and hit the ball hard, he's on offense and you definitely don't want to be on defense with those guys.” “Last year here against Carlos, I feel like I picked my level up in the opening set and at some point you feel like Carlos took it to another level and I couldn't stay there with him. He played so fast. It kind of feels like he's got constant pressure on you the entire time and you can't hit one ball that's without a ton of quality or he's on top of you, attacking the net. Same with Sinner. Sinner absolutely pounds the ball. If you don't play deep in the court and hit the ball hard, he's on offense and you definitely don't want to be on defense with those guys.” A post shared by Tommy Paul (@tommypaull) Paul is a combined 3-9 against Alcaraz and Sinner, though one of his wins against the latter came on grass back in 2022. Making only his fourth main-draw appearance at the All England Club, the 28-year-old aims to better his quarterfinal finish from last season despite landing in the same section as Sinner.“For tennis, this is the mecca,” said Paul, who This is where you want to play, where you dream about playing when you're young.”Hoping to build towards a classic of his own, Paul will next play Austria's Sebastian Ofner in the second round. “For tennis, this is the mecca,” said Paul, who This is where you want to play, where you dream about playing when you're young.”Hoping to build towards a classic of his own, Paul will next play Austria's Sebastian Ofner in the second round. Hoping to build towards a classic of his own, Paul will next play Austria's Sebastian Ofner in the second round. Mark your calendars.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


John Isner picks the American male tennis player he is most excited about and has the best chance to win Wimbledon
Source: The Tennis Gazette    Published: 2025-07-01 16:00:00

American men's players continue their search for an elusive Grand Slam title this month, hoping to be the one to end the drought. Former ATP number one Andy Roddick represents the last American man to win a Grand Slam title, having triumphed at the US Open in 2003. Pete Sampras meanwhile is the last American man to win Wimbledon, which is currently underway in London. Sampras was successful at Wimbledon in 2000, when he won the grass court Grand Slam for the fourth successive year. The nation's hopes of further success are now falling on a handful of players, namely Taylor Fritz, Ben Shelton, Frances Tiafoe and Tommy Paul. And speaking on Tennis Channel, former American professional John Isner has now shared which of his compatriots he is most excited about on the ATP Tour. Isner commented: “I think the one who excites me the most is probably Ben Shelton. His game is so huge. “He might take some early first round losses, which we saw in Queen's and Mallorca to Lerner Tien, but he picks up his level when the stage is big, so I expect him to play very well at Wimbledon. READ MORE: Learner Tien makes American tennis history after beating Ben Shelton in Mallorca “Once he can get his feet wet in the tournament he is a crazy tough out because he plays with such flair and confidence. He has such a big game, his serve is ridiculous. He is so athletic. “I think Ben Shelton in my mind is the guy that has probably the best chance to break through in a huge event like Wimbledon in the next three to five years.” Shelton has enjoyed superb progress on the ATP Tour this season, having recently broken the top 10 for the first time in his career. But he remains behind Fritz in that regard, with the 2024 US Open runner-up currently fifth in the ATP rankings. READ MORE: The next most likely American to win a Grand Slam following Ben Shelton's top 10 debut It is, however, European players who dominate the standings, with Italian Jannik Sinner at the very top of the pile. He is followed by Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz and German Alexander Zverev in second and third respectively, with Briton Jack Draper in fourth. And unfortunately for the American men, their European counterparts continue to dominate the sport as Wimbledon gets underway. Moreover, their female counterparts are doing their lack of success no favours, with Americans Madison Keys and Coco Gauff winning the 2025 Australian Open and French Open respectively. Fritz has come the closest to ending the painful men's drought in recent times, having lost last year's US Open final to Sinner. And Shelton also produced a valiant effort at the 2025 Australian Open, but once again it was the world number one who ended his hopes, this time in the semi-finals. Also excited about Shelton is Brad Gilbert, but Jimmy Connors favours Tommy Paul for Wimbledon success over him and Fritz.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


American tennis pro Jessica Pegula suffers stunning early Wimbledon exit
Source: Fox News    Published: 2025-07-01 15:36:00

This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. ©2025 FOX News Network, LLC. All rights reserved. Quotes displayed in real-time or delayed by at least 15 minutes. Market data provided by Factset. Powered and implemented by FactSet Digital Solutions. Legal Statement. Mutual Fund and ETF data provided by Refinitiv Lipper. Fox News Flash top sports headlines are here. Check out what's clicking on Foxnews.com. American tennis pro Jessica Pegula suffered a stunning and early exit from Wimbledon in the first round on Tuesday when she was defeated in under an hour by 116th-ranked Italian, Elisabetta Cocciaretto. Cocciaretto, 24, managed to pull off her first-ever top five win at Wimbledon with ease, defeating Pegula in straight sets 6-2, 6-3. Elisabetta Cocciaretto of Italy celebrates winning her women's first round singles match against Jessica Pegula of the U.S. at the Wimbledon Tennis Championships in London on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. (AP Photo/Joanna Chan) "To play here in such an unbelievable stadium and such an unbelievable tournament, it's a dream come true for me. I was so pumped to play Wimbledon this year," Cocciaretto said during her on-court interview following the match. CLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS "I played a really great champion. She's an unbelievable player, she's a great example for us." Pegula's loss comes just days after she defeated Iga Swiatek in straight sets on grass to win the Bad Homburg Open in Germany. Unlike in her match against the five-time Grand Slam champion, Pegula struggled against Cocciaretto's aggressive play, hitting only five winners and making 24 unforced errors. Jessica Pegula plays a shot against Poland's Iga Swiatek during the final match at the WTA tennis tournament in Bad Homburg, Germany, on Saturday, June 28, 2025. (AP Photo/Michael Probst) CARLOS ALCARAZ RUSHES OVER TO HELP ILL SPECTATOR AS RECORD-BREAKING HEAT TAKES TOLL ON WIMBLEDON MATCH "For this to happen today, it's disappointing. I don't know how else to put it," she said after the match. "I'm upset that I wasn't able to turn anything around. But at the same time, I do feel like she played kind of insane. Hats off to her. Kudos to her for playing at a high level that I couldn't match it today." Pegula's bad luck in the first round, which saw six of her first seven appearances at majors result in a first-round loss, came to an end in 2020, when she last lost to top-ranked women's pro Aryna Sabalenka at the French Open. Jessica Pegula of the U.S. leaves the court after losing to Elisabetta Cocciaretto of Italy during their women's first round singles match at the Wimbledon Tennis Championships in London on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. (Ben Whitley/PA via AP) CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP Tuesday's match was reminiscent of those early struggles. "This is definitely probably the worst result I've had all year," Pegula said. The Associated Press contributed to this report. Follow Fox News Digital's sports coverage on X, and subscribe to the Fox News Sports Huddle newsletter. Paulina Dedaj is a Sports Reporter for Fox News Digital. Who is Nikoloz Basilashvili, the Georgian Tennis Player Who Knocked Lorenzo Musetti Out of Wimbledon 2025?
Source: The Playoffs    Published: 2025-07-01 15:30:28

Basilashvili def. Musetti 6-2 4-6 7-5 6-1. 33-year-old Nikoloz Basilashvili possibly caused the upset of the men's Wimbledon Championships 2025 so far, as he took out No. 7 seed Lorenzo Musetti in dramatic fashion on Tuesday. The Georgian produced a relentless attack and left his Italian opponent with no answers in the Round of 128 clash. Basilashvili struck 15 aces and 48 winners en route to a four set victory. Ranked No. 126 in the world, Basilashvili started the match on a high note. He pushed Musetti from side to side, and the 2024 Wimbledon semifinalist had no answers to the shot making. As a result, he became the third Top-10 player in the men's draw to drop out of the competition in the opening round – after Holger Rune and Daniil Medvedev. Musetti's Bottega Veneta jacket deserved better 💔 pic.twitter.com/8uQrB83ZFv Normally adept at baseline exchanges and using the slice to his advantage, Musetti found himself on the attacking end for merely 17% of the match. He hit 21 winners and 29 unforced errors. On the other hand, Basilashvili brushed aside second set jitters to inch closer to the baseline and prevent Musetti from dictating rallies. “I was struggling to feel comfortable on the court from the beginning,” said the 23-year-old who led the ATP Tour for grass court wins in 2024. Born in Tbilisi, Georgia in 1992, Nikoloz Basilashvili is a two-time entrant into the Wimbledon third round (2015, 2022). The 33-year-old turned pro in 2008, and has been ranked as high as No. 16 in the world. Having started playing tennis at the age of 5, Basilashvili currently has just as many singles trophies to his name. He played his biggest final at the 2021 Indian Wells Masters, where he lost to Cameron Norrie. Nikoloz Basilashvili made his Grand Slam debut at the 2015 Roland Garros – he lost in the opening fixture to Thanasi Kokkinakis. The former Top-20 starlet has noteworthy wins against some of the world's best players. He has beaten the likes of Roger Federer (2021), Alexander Zverev (2019), Dominic Thiem (2017) as well as Stefanos Tsitsipas (2021), among others. Basilashvili beats Lorenzo Musetti 6-2 4-6 7-5 6-1 at WimbledonNikoloz knocks out last year's semifinalist. ✅1st top 10 win since 2022Bet you didn't see this one coming. 🇬🇪 pic.twitter.com/dXM3HJzeSi Singles Titles: 5 (Munich, Doha, Hamburg, Beijing, Hamburg) Doubles Titles: 0 Grand Slam Singles Performances: Australian Open – R3 (2018, 2019) Roland Garros – R3 (2017) Wimbledon – R3 (2015, 2022) US Open – R4 (2018) Others: Olympic Games – R3 (Tokyo 2020) Davis Cup Record – 10-7 (Image Credits: Imagn Images) A passionate sports fan through and through, I am currently pursuing my MA in Global Sports Journalism. I specialise in tennis and football writing at The PlayOffs, and I have prior experience working at EssentiallySports and Sportskeeda. Born and raised in Bengaluru, India, sport was my safe space right from my childhood. After trying my hand at multiple sports and representing my educational institutions in cricket, badminton and table tennis, I found sports media to be my calling. My message to the readers is don't be shy to express yourself - regardless of whether it's playing, talking or writing about sport. And if you're a fan Roger Federer, Lionel Messi and/or Stephen Curry - I'm your guy. Get the biggest stories delivered straight to you - for free!
